examples.text: a marginal improvement in weather conditions
The story will only be of marginal interest to our readers.
The difference between the two estimates is marginal.

definitions.definition: relating to or resulting from small changes

examples.text: All three companies reported marginal revenue growth.

definitions.definition: not part of a main or important group or situation

examples.text: Welsh was considered a marginal language.

definitions.definition: won or lost by a very small number of votes and therefore very important or interesting as evidence of public opinion

examples.text: They risk losing key marginal seats at the next election.

definitions.definition: written in the margin of a page
that cannot produce enough good crops to make a profit

wordOrigin: late 16th cent.: from medieval Latin marginalis, from margo, margin- ‘edge’.
